Aux:TextAnnotations.Aux:document_text: The leaders of Malaysia and the Philippines are both having to contend with capital outflows from emerging-markets amid signals from the Federal Reserve that it may pare monetary stimulus, sending many Asian currencies lower. Malaysia’s ringgit weakened 4.8 percent this quarter, more than the 3.1 percent loss in the Philippine peso, data compiled by Bloomberg show. Indonesia ’s rupiah dropped 11.2 percent, the Thai baht 4.2 percent and Singapore ’s dollar 1 percent. International investors have pulled about $44 billion from emerging-market stock and bond funds since the end of May, EPFR Global, the Cambridge, Massachusetts-based research company, reported Aug. 23. Malaysia is more vulnerable to capital outflows than some of its regional peers, partly due to its high reliance on foreign ownership of debt and the deterioration in the current account, according to Credit Suisse Group AG. The ringgit faces the most pressure among Asian currencies after the Indian rupee and Indonesia’s rupiah, Santitarn Sathirathai, Singapore-based economist at Credit Suisse, wrote in a research note Aug. 20.
